definition: The smallest unit of an element that retains the properties of that element.
A group of atoms bonded together, representing the smallest fundamental unit of a chemical compound.
A force of attraction between objects due to their mass.
The process by which green plants use sunlight to synthesize foods from carbon dioxide and water.
The change in the characteristics of a species over several generations due to natural selection.
Deoxyribonucleic acid; a molecule that carries the genetic instructions used in growth, development, and reproduction.
The speed of something in a given direction.
The rate at which an object's velocity changes with time.
A nerve cell that is the basic building block of the nervous system.
The minimum amount of any physical entity involved in an interaction in quantum physics.
A proposed explanation for a phenomenon, used as a starting point for further investigation.
A biological community of interacting organisms and their physical environment.
The branch of physics that deals with the relationships between heat and other forms of energy.
A measure of the amount of disorder or randomness in a system.
Atoms of the same element that have different numbers of neutrons.
An interaction that, when unopposed, will change the motion of an object.
A measure of the amount of matter in an object.
The capacity to do work or produce change.
A force that resists the motion of two surfaces sliding against each other.
The flow of electric charge through a conductor.
A force of attraction or repulsion that acts at a distance due to motion of electric charges.
The basic structural, functional, and biological unit of all living organisms.
An individual living entity that can react to stimuli, reproduce, grow, and maintain homeostasis.
A microscopic infectious agent that replicates only inside the living cells of an organism.
Single-celled microorganisms that can exist either as independent organisms or as parasites.
A sequence of DNA that contains the instructions to make a specific protein or set of proteins.
A change in the DNA sequence that can lead to variations in traits.
The central part of a cell that contains DNA and controls cell growth and reproduction.
The movement of water molecules through a semipermeable membrane from low to high solute concentration.
The passive spread of particles from areas of high concentration to areas of low concentration.
A biological catalyst that speeds up chemical reactions in living organisms.
A substance that donates hydrogen ions (H+) and has a pH less than 7.
A substance that accepts hydrogen ions (H+) and has a pH greater than 7.
A measure of how acidic or basic a substance is on a scale from 0 to 14.
A tabular arrangement of the chemical elements organized by atomic number and electron configuration.
A pure substance made of only one kind of atom.
A substance made of two or more different elements that are chemically bonded.
A combination of two or more substances that are not chemically bonded.
The path one object in space takes around another due to gravity.
An instrument that collects and magnifies light to observe distant objects in space.
A region in space where the gravitational field is so strong that nothing, not even light, can escape.
The scientific theory that the universe originated from a very dense and hot state and has been expanding ever since.
A large system of stars, gas, and dust bound together by gravity.
A space rock that enters Earth's atmosphere and burns up, often called a shooting star.
The theory explaining the movement of the Earth's plates and the processes that occur at their boundaries.
A sudden shaking of the ground caused by the movement of the Earth's tectonic plates.
A mountain that opens downward to a pool of molten rock beneath the Earth's surface.
The breaking down of rocks and minerals by natural forces such as wind, water, and temperature.
The process by which soil and rock are removed from the Earth's surface by wind or water flow.
The average weather conditions in an area over a long period.
The layer of gases that surrounds a planet, such as Earth.
